/etc/apache2/sites-available/default:

NameVirtualHost *
<VirtualHost *>

        ServerAdmin webmaster@localhost

        DocumentRoot /var/www/
        <Directory />
                Options None
                AllowOverride All
        </Directory>

</VirtualHost>

/var/www/.htaccess:
RewriteEngine On

[Sat Aug 04 22:35:42 2007] [error] [client 192.168.1.1] Options FollowSymLinks
or SymLinksIfOwnerMatch is off which implies that RewriteRule directive is
forbidden: /var/www/test
creator: rroeilck@no-spam.hu

See the section of "Per-Directory Rewrites" here:
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_rewrite.html#rewriterule

text:
thank you. but why need this permission? rewriting is not possible technically
without that?
creator: rroeilck@no-spam.hu
rbowen@apache.org
text:
It's a security precaution. A rewrite rule may be used as a symlink, in concept,
in that it can be used to tie a request to a file that is outside of the
document directory. Thus, in order to permit a user to put rewrite rules in a
.htaccess file, the system administrator must choose to permit this, by allowing
"Options FollowSymlinks". It has nothing to do with whether it is technically
possible. It has to do with giving the system admin the choice of whether to
permit this behavior.
